text: A full moon glows in the sky.  As we tilt downwards, Chri lights twinkle silently in the windows of a courtyard bro The cold December wind howls forlornly.  Although the str is empty, CHRISTMAS CAROLERS can be seen singing in front of one of the buildings. As the carolers move along, a WOMAN appears.  Groceries i tow, she makes her way through the courtyard of her build APPROACHING the doorway.  Fumbling with her keys, she enters.
Adjusting a small lightbulb on the wall in the foyer so t can see, the woman begins for the staircase but stops on a small package that's been left at its base.
is two-tiered.  Wrapped in green, it is tightly secured b bright red ribbon and bow.  Underneath the ribbon, a whit envelope peeks out with the name "KRISTINE" written on it

shakes her head in disbelief and approaches the gift slow After kneeling to scoop it up, she gazes at it for a mome after tearing open the card, discovers it is signed: "WIT NICK."  Sighing heavily in exasperation, KRISTINE scowls.

The bedroom lays quiet.  Although the drapes have been dr keep out the first rays of sunlight, it is grey and overc outside.  Against one wall on a mattress, an unseen lump slumbers uneasily beneath twisted bed sheets. Near the bed, we can see the soft neon glow of a digital radio on the nightstand shift from 6:59 to 7:00.  In an i the morning NEWSCAST fills the room-

(on radio) ... EBS news, with news from around the world.  It's seven a.m. in Chicago this Christmas Eve, coming up in this half hour, peace in the middle east is threatened as Jewish and Arab funda- mentalist groups clash in Jerusalem, leaving fifteen dead and twelve injured. Atheist groups continue to boycott at Daley Plaza in opposition to the city's annual holiday display...
A HAND reaches out for the alarm clock from beneath the c as the SLEEPER STIRS.

A Chicago newspaper with the headline AUTO PLANT LAYS OFF 50,000 WORKERS lies on the stoop.  A byline story adds EC CAN'T FIND YULE CHEER.  Another story at the bottom of th reads CHURCH ROBBED OF CHRIST CHILD STATUE.  The paper is dated DECEMBER 24TH. A FIGURE EXITS THE FOYER in a robe and slippers.  Reachin he picks up the paper and glances at the front page.  26. young man still, despite a creased brow and weariness in suggesting more than just a lack of sleep.  MEET NICK ALL Turning to head back in, he straightens a crooked CHRISTM WREATH hanging on the front door.

The skyline of Chicago looms wide-shouldered beneath a st grey sky.  Dreary is an understatement- this is a Chicago On Lake Shore Drive, a rain and dirt streaked Celica drif along an entry ramp signaling it's intention to merge wit oncoming traffic.  Once clear, it quickly enters the open lane and is almost side-swept by a speeding MAZDA ZX.
Reacting instantly to avert a collision, Nick watches as DRIVER of the Mazda passes, honks his horn and FLIPS HIM OFF.
Jeeesus...

Incredulous, Nick looks around to re-affirm whether or no was in the right.  On the car radio, the Phil Spector ver "Sleigh Ride" can be heard.  Twisting the wheel sharply, angrily fixes his gaze on the car that has almost run him road and filled with adrenaline, he hits the gas.
Nick's car guns forward in an effort to catch up and pass speeding Mazda.
Closing the distance between himself and the Mazda, Nick suddenly hits the brakes-
As a POLICE CAR pulls out from the side of the road in pu of the ZX.
who SMIRKS and salutes the driver of the sportscar as he by-
And a Merry Christmas to you too my friend-
Nick's laughter can be heard as  his car speeds on toward downtown.
Within an office cubicle, Nick gazes lethargically at the screen on his desk.  Around him, fellow employees carry o tasks within the large AD AGENCY they all occupy.
flips off his computer, his co-worker JAY enters with som folders-
Hey hey...
Hey Jay.
What's up
Nothing.  I just finished up that ad for that stupid mailing.
How's it going?
Not good enough for a raise-
Surprised, Jay sits on the edge of the desk.
You get your review?
Nick nods, looking up at his friend.
This morning.  Of all days, can you believe that? (beat) You're due for one, right?
Nah, I haven't been here long enough. Two more months-
(sarcastically) Two months... two years... I'm begin- ing to think we can never be here long enough for that "raise"...
Jay commiserates with Nick.
I can't believe it... I mean, your ad copy's great, the mail pieces are sound... it's all bringing in business...
Yeah, well... not enough I guess. (more to himself) I can't believe I went to college, got a degree... all it's gotten me is the chance to pimp for this ad agency.
Jay begins to laugh but on seeing Nick's impassive demean catches himself.
Nick, it's Christmas Eve.  You know- holiday spirit... be of good cheer?
Nick snorts.

"God Rest Ye Merry Gentlemen" is about all I can think of right now, that and the ghost of bills past, present, and future.  I just wish I can get out of here so I can finish up shopping for my family-
Nick shrugs.
I'm sorry man, I don't mean to trash your mood.  It's just that I'm...
A  little short on Christmas spirit.
(dejectedly) Yeah.
Jay pulls aside the folders he's carrying to reveal a fla brightly wrapped Christmas gift.
Well... maybe this'll help.
Nick is taken totally aback.  Jay passes the gift along, pleased at himself for having cheered up his friend somewhat.
Aw Jay... you shouldn't have...
But I did.
Nick looks the package over.
Look Jay, I didn't have a chance to do any shopping for anyone here... I... I didn't get anything for anyone-
Jay smiles chidingly.
I figured that.
Nick smiles crookedly and looks over the package.
Should I open it now?
Considering your mood I would say the sooner, the better.
Nick tears away at the wrapping.
It's nothing fancy or anything, just something I picked up at a used book- store.
Nick holds up a book entitled "HOW TO BREAK INTO FILM". He laughs.
Am I that obvious?
Jay nods at some of the movie posters tacked to the walls Nick's cubicle.
I know you're always looking ahead.
Nick flips through the book gratefully.
Yeah.  Just don't tell anyone around here, they'd probably can me before I could get something real lined up.
Jay chuckles.
Thanks man.  This's really made my day.
Jay smiles, shakes Nick's hand and gets up to leave.
(looking at his watch) No problem man.  I gotta fly... I'm meeting Tammy- Merry Christmas.
Yeah, you too.
Nick watches after Jay, looks down again at his gift and within the solitude of his cubicle, gathers his things to

Around the area of the Loop where Nick's office is situat Christmas shoppers bustle as the last minute rush begins. Nick walks out of his office building towards Michigan Av and passes a SALVATION ARMY WORKER.
Help the needy sir?
Nick tosses a few coins into the pot.
Thank you, you have a Merry Christmas-
Yeah...
As Nick continues on, he approaches a BAG LADY.  Dressed layered and ratty clothing, she seems to carry all of her belongings in the shopping basket she drags behind her.
Could you spare some change sir? It'll help with the downpayment on my new condo... (beat) Please...

Nick slows his step.  Disarmed by the woman's self-effaci humor, he can't help but be charmed by her approach while sympathizing with the seriousness of her plight.  Digging into his pocket, Nick pulls out a five and passes it to t woman.
Thank you sir.  Merry Christmas!
Nick nods.  Pausing to watch her move on, Nick pulls his coat collar close as a sudden wind kicks up.  He then con on down the street.
Nick guides his car through Lincoln Park towards Broadway Through his windshield, he takes in the images of a CHRIS

outside.  Traffic fills the street.  Holiday banners hang streetlamps while strings of Christmas lights twinkle fro branches of barren trees.  Ignoring the signals, some ped walk into the street causing even more congestion. On the sidewalk, a man dressed in a Santa Claus suit ring bell to attract last minute shoppers.  He waves as Nick p Up the street, shoppers bustle hurriedly in and out of th various storefronts oblivious of each other.  One woman w two kids in tow argues angrily with a meter maid who is a to issue her a ticket because the meter just expired. At another corner, a couple just off work meet and enter for a drink with some friends before retiring home for th evening. They ignore a disabled panhandler begging near t
Nick sees a solitary old man kneeling.  Laying a wreath a grave of his deceased wife, he then rises and crosses him

head_text.subj: AS IT STARTS TO GET DARK

text: Nick sees a Christmas tree lot closing up shop.  Along th sidewalk, some indigent people shuffle slowly in no parti hurry since they have no home to go to.
Nick gazes almost hypnotically at the array of walkmen, h and other electronic toys in front of him.  The price tag wrapped in holiday bows, are astronomical.  A CLERK comes up.
Can I help you sir?  Sir, can I help you find something?
Nick fixates on the display, his attention a million mile
Sir.  Is there something I can help you find?
Nick glances at the clerk, at once snapping out of his da
Oh... no. (sheepishly) If I can't find it myself, I don't think you could help me.
Patting the clerk's shoulder gently, Nick moves towards t
Thanks anyway though.

A key is heard at the door.  In an instant, Nick enters t creative hodgepodge of his darkened apartment and in flip on the light, reveals all of his dreams and frustrations. In the livingroom, a drawing board stands in mute testimo to the dozens of sketches in various states of completion taped to it. Along with Nick's graduation certificates, some framed mo posters on the wall overlook an entire shelf bursting at with movie books.  In the front room, a cluttered PC work is situated between an artificial fireplace and steamed u window.  Piled on top of the television cabinet nestled i corner are some videotapes while next to where the couch dwarf-sized Christmas tree decorated with dimestore ornam tilts uneasily to one side.

dumps his packages on the couch.  Passing an array of hol greeting cards displayed atop the fireplace, he moves som aside on his desk to reveal an ANSWERING MACHINE. Undoing his coat, he pushes PLAYBACK-

... Hello Nick, this is your Mom. Your sister and brother just got in and we're wondering when we're all going to see you.  Please let us... please let me know when you'll be coming home so I can make up your room.  We all miss you.
The machine beeps to the next message.
Hey dude, it's Buddy.  A bunch of us are meeting at D'Agostino's to- night around 6:30 for a drink before heading home for Christmas.  Give me a call... let me know if you're coming. Later...

A sudden pounding is heard at the front door, startling N Stopping the answering machine, he goes over to open it a KRISTINE standing beyond.  She glares at him harshly.  In hands are the two PACKAGES that were left in her foyer th night before.
I thought we talked about this.
Attempting to avoid Kristine's wrath, Nick sheepishly ave attention elsewhere.
Yeah.  Um... you want to come in?
Not answering, Kristine enters.  Shutting the door behind Nick uncomfortably begins to tidy up some things as she f arms.
Nick, we talked about this.  You just never listen...
Nick stands staring at Kristine, measuring how to respond
For Christ's sake Kristine, what was I supposed to do, just forget about you?
We're not going out anymore, I told you not to get me anything.
Nick is at a loss for words.  Her rage vented, Kristine s bit, but doesn't stand down.
Why did you do it?
A long beat passes in which Nick collects his thoughts. replies quietly-
It's Christmas.  I thought it'd be the right thing to do.
Kristine paces frustratedly.
Oh come on Nick.  This isn't about Christmas.  You go out and buy me a necklace, and a tape of a movie we watched together during a different time... how am I supposed to take this?
Kristine, I got you the necklace, because I thought it would look good on you.  I bought you the movie because I knew it was one of your favorites from when you were a little girl...
Nick throws his arms up.
Why do we have to argue about this?  It made sense to get them because I figured they'd be things you would like...
(quietly) But I told you I couldn't accept anything from you-

(angry now) That was after I bought them.  You don't want them, fine.  Give them away.  Throw them away.  But I'll be damned if I'm gonna return a Christmas gift that I bought for somebody.  Anybody, not just you. (frustrated) God why do you have to make such a big deal out of this?
Because it always seems that you are calling, or doing things for reasons you're not being up front about.
Nick plops down wearily onto the sofa.
And just what am I not being "up front" about?
Wanting to get back together. Manipulating Christmas for some- thing else.
Nick stares at her, then looks down, cornered by some of truth in her statement.  He massages his temples as Krist sits down next to him.

(gently) I'm not trying to be mean.  I think it's very sweet of you.  But some- times I don't think even you realize some of the reasons why you do the things you do, and it's always going to make me keep my distance.  That's why I told you not to get me anything. That's why it makes me uncomfortable.
Concentrating on the wall, Nick tries to gather his thoug then speaks-
Kristine, I knew you weren't going home for Christmas, I wanted to do something nice. (his voice cracking a little) I don't get through Christmas very well.  Being alone doesn't make it any easier.
SILENCE.  Outside, the wind HOWLS through the apartment's cracks.

Nick... I get lonely too this time of year, I know it's hard... but thinking about the past is dangerous. This relationship does not work.  We do things too differently.  It makes me sad to think that, when I can re- member all of the things we shared.
(glumly) Like our hard heads.
Disarmed momentarily, Kristine allows a smile.
Like our hard heads. (regaining her composure) We've gotta stop doing this.
Kristine rises, holding out the necklace and tape to Nick
I don't have the receipts.
Kristine shakes her head.
Please Nick.  No more.
Nick nods.  The storm between them has passed, despite th delicate truce.  He gets up and walks her to the door.
what are your plans this evening?
I don't know yet.  How 'bout you?
I'm having dinner with my room- mate and her family, then I'm heading out for midnight mass with them in the suburbs.
Sounds like a blast.
The two stop at the door.
Well... I figure it's the best place to get my head together with everything else being the way it is.
Yeah...
Not knowing how to say goodbye, Nick shifts awkwardly.
Well.  Merry Christmas.
A beat passes.  Caught up in her emotions, Kristine embra Nick suddenly, holding him close.
Merry Christmas Nick.

Nick watches after Kristine as she exits the apartment an then closes the door slowly.  After pacing the length of livingroom, he kicks a metal waste can across the room an then surveys the sudden emptiness in his apartment-
Some cars pass this cozy little Wrigleyville saloon known D'AGOSTINO'S.
Last call...!

In the corner of the back room, a television set tuned in "IT'S A WONDERFUL LIFE" rests on top of a wooden perch ju out from the wall.  Below it, Nick sits exasperated over before his pal BUDDY and some other friends who have gath to share a last minute drink to toast the holiday-
(to Nick) ... I'm really sorry man.  You two still gonna keep in touch?
I don't know!  It's a little hard trying to salvage something, when I still can't figure out why we went bad in the first place!
Buddy squints his eyes at Nick, trying to keep up-
You know what I mean?
A beat passes.
Kind of.
Nick snorts derisively at himself.
Well.  Maybe I just gotta let it go and give it a rest.
Looking at his friend empathetically, Buddy tries to offe some words of solace.

No.  No, I do understand.  Re- member last year when I broke up with Jennifer just before the holidays?  I never thought I'd get through it if it weren't for my family.  That's what the holidays are for man, that's what you've gotta concentrate on, is your family. (raising his beer) Haven't you been home yet?
No.  I managed putting it off 'til tomorrow.
Disappointed by Nick's attitude, Buddy shakes his head wi disapproving look.

(defensively) Oh, c'mon Buddy, you know how my family is.  Everybody's so busy talking, nobody ever listens- (beat) It's not anyone's fault, it's just that... everything's already so stressed out that Christmastime, just makes it worse.
You'd think twice about saying that if you ever lost them.
Nick stares at Buddy a moment, then looks down.

When my mom got diagnosed with cancer this year, all I could think about was how important it was to be home with her, because none of us knew how much more time she had. That's when you realize everything else is really bullshit, when all the things that make sense look like they're just about to be yanked out from under you!  And look at her now... she's in remission!
Nick looks back up at his friend, recognizing the truth in what he says.
(quietly) Thank God for that.
Buddy nods.  It's obvious that almost losing his mother h left an everlasting impression.
You know it.  She fought it all the way and won.
He lifts his beer.
To my mom.
Nick raises his bottle.
God bless her.
Sipping from their drinks, the two silently ponder it all the television set above, GEORGE BAILEY sits at MARTINI'S BAR praying for a miracle.  Noticing, Buddy yells up at the barkeep-
Hey Bob!!!  Isn't anything else on?

BOB the bartender holds up the remote control and aims it at the television.  Flipping channels only reveals "It's Wonderful Life" on almost every other station although at different points in the movie.  Everyone in the bar howls laughter.  Buddy leans back to pull a few bills from his while Nick contemplates George Bailey's dilemma.
(signaling Nick to rise) Christmas is what you make of it pal. If Jimmy Stewart can get through it, so can the rest of us.

Nick and Buddy leave D'Agostino's while exchanging "GOODBYES" and "MERRY CHRISTMASES" with their other friends. As the group separates and the lights in the bar grow dim the two start down the icy street.

You know what really sucks Buddy, is that even if stuff was great with my family, even if I was still on decent terms with Kristine, even if I was halfway satisfied with my job, something still wouldn't seem right.
Like what?
Like everything!  Take a look around us, everybody's hurting!  I saw this bag lady today, all she wanted was some money so she could eat...
Well did you give her something?
Yeah I gave her something... but does it matter?  Is it gonna make a difference?
(firmly) As long as you put forth the effort, it does...
Buddy examines his friend, not sure of what other comfort he can offer.  He then holds his hand out.
Come on...
A beat passes.  Extending his hand, Nick shakes with Budd
(sighing) Yeah, well... thanks for listening.
You've been there just as many times for me.  Merry Christmas "Saint Nick"... Get home safely.
I will.
The friends part.  As Buddy disappears down the street. Nick looks up at the moon.
No snow. (beat) It should snow for Christmas.
As Nick gazes up into the night sky, a COUPLE pass intent on getting somewhere on time.  Distracted by them, he watches as they scurry past and seeing their destinati follows after them.

Following after the couple, Nick finds himself in front o MUSIC BOX THEATER, a small, refurbished movie palace situated in the middle of the neighborhood.  Beneath the marquee, a group of people stand in line waiting to buy tickets. Looking up, Nick sees the words:
A group of HIGH SCHOOLERS carrying JINGLE BELLS catch Nick's attention.  As they notice him, they all chi "Merry Christmas".  Nick nods, indicating the theater.
Which one's playing next?
"It's A Wonderful Life."  Last show too...
Why would you pay to see "It's A Wonderful Life" when you can see it at home for free?
Are you kidding?  They sing Christ- mas Carols right before the show! Come on, you'll have some fun...
Ah... I don't know...
Sensing that Nick is alone on Christmas Eve, the kids try coercing him into checking out the show.
Come on...
But you'll need one of these-
The girl passes him one of the JINGLE BELL STRINGS. Nick studies them amusedly.
Thanks.
Make sure you put them to good use!

As the high schoolers move on, Nick shakes his head and looks back at the other holiday revelers surrounding Intrigued at their enthusiasm, he clutches the jingle bel close and gets in line to buy a ticket.

The house lights are dim.  Excited audience members have already filled the small movie palace.  Along the auditor walls, garland and ornaments decorate the terra cotta fac reminiscent of an ornate Spanish village.  In the back of theater, Nick enters with his jingle bells.  Up near the lyrics are projected onto the screen while an ORGANIST playing a huge WURLITZER and the THEATER MANAGER both guide the audience through the last verse of "SANTA CLAUS IS COMING TO TOWN".  As the song finishes, the audience ROARS its approval.

That was great!!!  Once again, I want to welcome you all to our Annual Holiday Sing Along!!!  If you haven't been here for this before, although something tells me most of you have,all you have to do is follow along with the lyrics on the screen as our previous song takes on a different... "twist"-

As the organist begins, the theater is FILLED with the po of the Wurlitzer's old-fashioned sound.  Energized by it, takes a seat as the theater manager leads the audience in alternate version of "SANTA CLAUS IS COMING TO TOWN" with lyrics behind him on the immense screen that concent on the holidays more ironic aspects-
"Oh, you'd better get set, to cough up some dough... here's the sad news in case you don't know... Santa Claus is coming... to town...."
Nick laughs.
"Your wife gets the gifts... the kids get the thrills... first of the year you'll get all the bills... Santa Claus is coming, to town!!!"
As Nick watches the crowd around him, he catches sight of the high schoolers who smile and wave their bells at h
"... And you'll be very lucky... if RIGHT at Christmas time... old Santa Claus brings YOU a tie from the well known five and dime..."
Pulling his bells out, Nick waves them back and follows s as the theater manager winds the audience towards the fin
"Oh, you're gonna be broke so smile and sit still, if he don't get you INCOME TAX will... Santa Claus is coming... TO TOWN!!!"
The audience applauds wildly.  As they die down, the mana continues.
If you were here for the last film, you should already have this one down. Put your hearts into it, because you never know what magic it will cause...

"WHITE CHRISTMAS" is played.  As Nick sings along with the audience, we can tell he seems to finally be filled w some warmth.  As the song winds down, a special film loop in the projection booth causes it to look as if it's SNOW within the theater.  Still singing, the audience members their hands together in wild approval. As the song ends, the curtains part to reveal the familia of the LIBERTY FILMS logo while the first strains of the opening music to "IT'S A WONDERFUL LIFE" can be heard-
That was great!!! From the Music Box staff to you and yours, have a safe and happy holiday, and thanks again for coming!!!
As the manager and organist depart from the auditorium, N applauds with the rest of the audience as the FILM BEGINS

Outside, a mild snowfall that has already accumulated two makes the Music Box Theater and all of Southport Avenue l like a postcard.  Even after the show ends, small flakes falling as the audience members stream out. Exiting the theater, Nick looks around and smiles.  He is definitely in better spirits.

As Nick begins his journey home through the snow, he sees LITTLE GIRL gazing out from her open apartment window alo the avenue reaching out and catching snowflakes.  As she sight of him, Nick smiles at her and waves up.
Hey mister.
Merry Christmas!  Hey... you be careful up there!
Have you seen Santa Claus?
No, not yet.  It's still early though.  I'm sure he'll be along while you're asleep.
I don't know.  Momma doesn't think he'll come.
Nick's eyebrow raises, a little stunned by her statement. Wondering what she means, he carefully presses.
Well why does your momma think that?
The little girl shrugs.
She said first he has to visit the families whose daddies are working.
Oh.  Doesn't your Daddy work?
No.  He's dead.  My momma works though.

Nick gazes speechlessly at the little girl.  As he puts t two together realizing what hard times the little girl's mother must be facing, she suddenly APPEARS next to her daughter.  Looking a little haggard, the young mother pic daughter up.
Come on honey, it's time to go to bed-
Thinking quickly, Nick digs into his coat pocket-
WAIT!
The MOTHER looks down, noticing Nick for the first time. Wary, she begins to lower the window.
Please, hold on...
The mother pauses.
What do you want?
Well, your little girl told me how you don't think Santa Claus is coming...
The mother's face tenses.  A combination of SHAME and RESENTMENT.  Before she can answer though, Nick has pulle the JINGLE BELLS from his pocket.
Since he's so busy, he wasn't sure if he'd be able to get everywhere either, but I saw him.
The little girl's eyes brighten.
Yeah!!!  I saw him, and he gave me these, and he wanted to make sure that you get them...
Nick takes a step back and tosses the jingle bells up tow window.  They bounce off the wall and fall back down to h Nick on the head.
(grabbing them) Wait a minute.  Get ready now... catch!!!
He throws the bells again, clearing the window.  As they through, the little girl grabs them-
(pleased with himself) You take care of those... they belonged to Rudolph!
See mommy, I told you Santa would bring something!
Nick looks up at the mother nervously, not knowing what t expect.
I hope I wasn't out of place there.  I...
The mother shakes her head and holds her lips tight for f crying.  Not wishing to embarrass the woman, Nick quickly moves on.  Watching after him thankfully, she shuts her w and moves out of view.

Nick walks through the silent snow swept streets.  Around the three streets Belmont, Lincoln and Ashland crisscross the streets' juncture is a wide open intersection overwhi abandoned hulk of an out-of-business department store loo Christmas decorations are visible on some buildings, as w twinkling lights.  The avenue itself though, with the exc of one or two passing cars, is barren.

looks up at the sky, focusing on the constellations. One star shines brighter than the others, TWINKLING in th Nick snorts cynically.  For a moment though, he suddenly imagines that he hears angels singing.  Realizing that th is absurd, he focuses back on the street and sees beyond darkened storefronts a Gothic CHURCH SPIRE cutting upward through the low drifting clouds.  Curious as to the origi the singing, Nick starts walking-

Nick finds himself standing in front of ST. ALPHONSUS CHU Blanketed with snow, the scale of the structure is humbli is the facade.  On each of the four walls situated at the of the steeple, a Roman numeral clock face bears the time O'CLOCK MIDNIGHT. Nick gazes at the open doors of St. Alphonsus.  A few lat can be seen arriving.  Drifting towards the steps, Nick j their ranks and enters.

The church is only half-full, not quite matching the numb seen earlier within the Music Box.  A CHOIR sings "O HOLY NIGHT" in a loft at the rear.  Entering from the back, Ni about taking in the solid stone columns and meticulously varnished woodwork.  Interspersed along the walls between half-dozen confessionals are brass plaques depicting the stations of the cross.  Overlooking the altar is a staine window with a giant crucifix hanging in front of it.  Off the side is a small NATIVITY CRГ€CHE. Passing some worshippers, Nick advances respectfully up a aisle towards the front of the church so that he may get view of the CRГ€CHE.  Approaching it, he stops to notice CHRIST CHILD FIGURE is missing. Nick looks around at the congregation gathered for the mi service.  No one seems to notice that the Christ Child fi gone.  Distressed by this, Nick glances around for an USH on spotting one, quickly shuffles over.
(whispering) Excuse me-
The usher notices Nick.
Yes?
The Christ Child figure...
The usher looks at Nick quizzically.
It's just that... your Christ Child figure is missing.
The usher nods her head in affirmation, totally unruffled Nick is incredulous.
I'm sorry, but hasn't anybody noticed?
Oh yes, it's been missing since yesterday.  Some teenagers stole it from Father Jacobse, although I can't imagine what they plan on doing with it-
is having a hard time dealing with the usher's complacenc in the matter.  Around them, the congregation has quieted for the PRIEST who has appeared, preparing to start his sermon.
(to usher) It's Christmas Eve!  Isn't anybody upset about it?
The usher looks at Nick with a serenity in her eyes that volumes-
The child may be missing, but his spirit is still in our hearts.
Mesmerized by the service around him and the people that come together in worship, Nick glances towards the altar FATHER JACOBSE begins.
Although many of us face troubled times these days, we must always keep in mind that Christmas, is not the holiday where we get what we want... but when we get what we need...
As the impact of Father Jacobse's words hit Nick like a h he is suddenly transported back to the events of the past hours-
Jay passes his gift along to Nick-
Thanks man.  This's really made my day.
Jay smiles, shakes Nick's hand and gets up to leave.
(looking at his watch) No problem man.  I gotta fly... I'm meeting Tammy- Merry Christmas.
Yeah, you too.
Nick digs into his pocket and pulls out some money for th
Thank you sir.  Merry Christmas!
Buddy counsels Nick at D'Agostino's-
... That's what the holidays are for man, that's what you've gotta concentrate on, is your family. (raising his beer) Haven't you been home yet?
Kristine embraces Nick, holding him close.
Merry Christmas Nick.
The high school girl passes Nick one of her JINGLE BELL STRINGS.
Make sure you put them to good use!
Nick throws the jingle bells up to the little girl as the looks down thankfully.
What do you want?
Well, your little girl told me how you don't think Santa Claus is coming. Since he's so busy, he wasn't sure if he'd be able to get everywhere either, but I saw him.
The little girl's eyes brighten.
Yeah!!!  I saw him, and he gave me these, and he wanted to make sure that you get them...
Nick in the electronics store, with the clerk offering as
